terms.term: Software Development Life Cycle - the process used to design, develop, and test high-quality software.
The use of artificial intelligence tools like large language models to help with software development tasks.
Large Language Model - an AI system trained on vast amounts of text data that can generate human-like text and assist in various tasks.
The AI assistant used in this project to help with development tasks.
A developer working independently on a software project without a team.
The phase of identifying and documenting what the software should do.
The phase of planning how the software will be structured and function.
The phase where the actual code is written according to the design specifications.
The process of evaluating a system to identify any gaps, errors, or missing requirements.
The process of releasing the software to the production environment.
The process of modifying and updating software after deployment to correct faults and improve performance.
Software Requirements Specification - a document that describes the requirements for a software system.
A streamlined version of a Software Requirements Specification designed for solo developers.
User Experience - the overall experience of a person using a product, especially in terms of how easy or pleasing it is to use.
User Interface - the means by which users interact with a software application.
A streamlined approach to user experience and interface design for solo developers.
Specific questions or instructions given to an AI assistant to get helpful responses for development tasks.
A prioritization technique used in requirements management (Must have, Should have, Could have, Won't have).
A development approach where the software is built incrementally, with each iteration adding functionality.
The use of software tools to execute tests automatically and compare actual outcomes with expected outcomes.
The process of manually testing software for defects without the use of automation tools.
A testing approach that prioritizes testing efforts based on the risk of failure and impact of features.
The practice of merging all developer working copies to a shared mainline several times a day.
A system that records changes to a file or set of files over time so that specific versions can be recalled later.
A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.
A platform and cloud-based service for software development and version control using Git.
A systematic examination of computer source code intended to find and fix mistakes.
The implied cost of additional rework caused by choosing an easy solution now instead of using a better approach that would take longer.
The process of restructuring existing computer code without changing its external behavior.
Written text or illustrations that accompany software to explain how it works or how to use it.
A file that contains information about other files in a directory or archive, typically providing basic information about the software.
